Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Associating Polymers: From Association to Segmental and Chain Relaxations
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Associating polymers are a class of polymeric materials that are promising candidates for a large number of applications ranging from energy-related fields to biomedical technologies. This research focuses on fundamental understanding of how the specially designed interactions control molecular motions and macroscopic properties of associating polymers. A broad range of experimental techniques will be employed to analyze molecular motions on different time and length scales, and their dependence on chemical structure and rigidity/flexibility of the individual polymer molecules. A description of structure-properties relationship in this relatively new class of materials will also be developed. This knowledge is important for rational design and synthesis of novel "smart" materials with self-healing and stimuli-responsive properties for many future technological applications. It will have an impact on various fields of science and engineering, including materials science, physics, chemistry and biophysics. A significant part of this project is the education of specialists through development of graduate courses and active involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in research. Attention will also be paid to working with underrepresented groups and to outreach to K-12 students. This research promotes collaborations with international colleagues and with the Spallation Neutron Source and Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Associating polymers, formed by reversible non-covalent intermolecular interactions, include a wide spectrum of fundamentally and technologically important materials. Rational design, synthesis, and fabrication of novel associating polymers require a deep fundamental understanding of how the local reversible interactions and backbone flexibility affect the macroscopic properties of associating polymers. Despite intense attention and effort in the past, the chain and structural dynamics in associating polymers remain poorly understood, especially in the case of the melt state. In this project, the chain and structural dynamics in model associating polymers will be studied by a combination of rheology, dielectric spectroscopy, light scattering, and neutron scattering. New experimental methods and protocols will be developed by borrowing existing concepts and techniques from the fields of conventional polymers, hydrogen-bonded glass-forming liquids, and ionic solutions. In addition, the current theoretical models for associating polymers will be critically examined. This project aims to establish the phenomenological foundation for understanding the dynamics of associating polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Associating polymers present a relatively new class of materials that can exhibit properties of small molecules or properties of polymers, depending on conditions used. These materials are based on dynamic bonds and exhibit unique self-healing and time programmable properties that find broad applications in many current and future technologies. Moreover, they are easily recyclable, that improves sustainability of current technologies.  However, our understanding of the dynamics in associating polymers remains limited.

This project was focused on fundamental understanding of segmental dynamics and viscoelastic properties, the role of associating groups interactions, chain flexibility and microphase separation in associating polymer melts. During the award period we developed experimental approach based on combination of dielectric spectroscopy and rheology that can analyze characteristic dissociation energy of the dynamic bonds, characteristic time of dynamic bonds switching, and several other critical parameters. We formulated a model approach that can describe viscoelatic properties of the associating polymers on a qualitative level. Based on the developed knowledge, we designed and synthesized materials with unique viscoelastic properties that behave as small molecular liquids at high temperatures, as high molecular weight polymers at intermediate temperatures, and as a crosslinked rubber at lower temperatures. We also synthesized polymers with extreme extensibility (more than 5000%) and self-healing properties. The developed during this award knowledge is instrumental in design of novel functional materials with unique properties, including self-healing and easy recyclability.

We also analyzed the role of ionic interactions and chain flexibility on structure, dynamics and ionic conductivity of polymerized ionic liquids. We developed a model that can predict the glass transition temperature Tg of the polymerized ionic liquids from knowledge of their chemical structure. We also unraveled details of the mechanisms controlling ionic conductivity in polymer electrolytes. All these developments are important for design of novel solid polymer electrolytes with high ionic conductivity that will enable solid state batteries with performance far exceeding current liquid-based batteries.

Besides these scientific achievements, the NSF funding helped significantly in development of human resources and education. Six graduate students (three of them are female students) were actively involved in this research, and four of them have graduated and working in industry and academia. Postdoctoral associates who worked on this project got faculty positions and staff positions in National Laboratory.

We also pay attention to working with school students. For several years during each summer Dr. Sokolov presents a lecture to about 100 high school students attending the Governor?s summer school at the University of Tennessee. This school attracts the best high-school students from the entire state of Tennessee.
